awd_titl_txt: Research in the Origins and Development of Modern Cartography
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Overview 

This project studies the development of cartography in the nineteenth century when the modern concept of cartography as the science of the measurement of the world first originated and flourished. An international team of expert editors will solicit, guide, interpret, and integrate the research of over two hundred contributors to develop a comprehensive and coherent account of the evolution of cartography in a social and cultural context. They will trace multiple facets of this new concept of mapping science within a wide variety of scientific, technological, political, governmental, economic, and artistic contexts. The increasing role of civil and military authorities in collecting, mapping, and using scientific data as well as the rise of mass cartographic literacy and the democratization of map use will also be studied. The final product will be an encyclopedic volume; there will also be a free, online publication of the volume.

Intellectual Merit

This research project promotes new scholarship that will enable intellectuals, specialists, and the public to understand the critical, formative period for modern spatial technologies and science. It stands to make significant contributions to the understanding of contemporary cartography, geography, and science. It will explain and interpret the origins and formation of modern cartography, and so of modern science, as cultural and social phenomena. The editorial team confirmed their volume design through extensive consultations with leading experts on science, technology, and cartography in the era. Strategies for working with contributors, for guiding their research, and for meticulously fact checking their findings were refined through the preparation of similar volumes on cartography in the eighteenth and twentieth century. The Press has already commissioned peer reviews of the design and methodology and has pre-approved the volume for publication. 

Broader Impacts

As an interpretive guide to the origins of modern cartography (and more generally to the socio-cultural constitution of modern science and technology), it will serve to create scholarly networks and to stimulate innovative and interdisciplinary research. Its comprehensive content will enable researchers and readers to more effectively study the interrelationships of mapping sciences and technologies and their social impacts. The free, online publication of will capitalize on the widespread fascination and engagement with maps to publicly promote its analysis of the nature of cartography, science, and technology. In uncovering and exploring the foundations of modern cartography, the project will help create a sophisticated public understanding of geospatial science and technology.

por.por_cntn:
This award has supported the research needed to prepare Cartography in the Nineteenth Century. The volume is edited by Prof. Roger Kain, School of Advanced Study, University of London, UK, with the support of three coeditors (Peter Collier, formerly of University of Portsmouth, UK; Imre Demhardt, University of Texas at Arlington; Carla Lois, University of Buenos Aires, Argentina) and two associate editors (Peter Barber, formerly British Library, UK; Peter Nekola, Imago Mundi). The volume includes the work of a similarly international team of 196 expert authors.

Cartography in the Nineteenth Century will be the final publication in, The History of Cartography, a six-volume series prepared by the History of Cartography Project at the University of Wisconsin–Madison. The series lays the foundation for a new understanding of maps and their history across all cultures and periods. It addresses fundamental questions about how humans experience and represent space. Who were the mapmakers, and why did they make maps? What methods and technologies did they use? How did those mapping strategies evolve? The History of Cartography is known as an accurate, comprehensive, and definitive work of reference. The broad intellectual significance of the series is demonstrated by the popularity of the four volumes that have been placed online for free access by the publisher, the University of Chicago Press; a global community interested in map history has accessed the chapters of those four volumes almost four million times since July 2011 (see www.press.uchicago.edu/books/HOC/).

Cartography in the Nineteenth Century has specifically fostered new and innovative research into maps and mapping during the period 1790–1914. This was the formative period of modern spatial technologies and sciences. To tell the history of the origins and development of modern cartography is to tell the history of the nineteenth-century sciences, of their increasing use of spatial representation and their intellectual and social significance. To do so, the volume studies each of the modes of mapping: property, boundary, topographical, marine, geographical, celestial, thematic, urban, and geodetic. Each mode comprised a particular constellation of institutions, spatial conceptions, geospatial needs, and types of maps. Moreover, there were cross-cutting organizational contexts: commercial mapmaking and the public sphere (map trade, map collecting); and state formation (administrative mapping, military mapping). It is possible to give due attention to all of these different aspects of cartography because the volume takes the form of an interpretive encyclopedia. Entries about each mode and organizational context are grouped together so readers can explore the practices and technologies of each mapping science as they have changed and developed during the nineteenth century. Other entries address exemplary individuals, specific technologies, important maps and atlases, and key themes. By following liberal cross-references, readers can construct new narratives of the growth of cartographic science. At the same time, a detailed index gives direct access to precise information.

The volume’s editors have encouraged the authors to think about maps and cartography in new ways. This has led to coverage extending well beyond the standard narrative of nineteenth-century map history, which has emphasized Humboldtian science, the rise of thematic mapping, and the impact of lithographic printing. The editors also solicited new research on the adoption of Western mapping practices across Asian cultures, even as traditional mapping practices persisted.

Every volume of The History of Cartography series is necessarily substantial. Cartography in the Nineteenth Century will contain one million words and one thousand full-color images. The 409 encyclopedic entries are all thoroughly checked to ensure that their information is correct and complete; all names of people, institutions, and maps are made consistent; and the content of each entry is integrated into the whole volume and the entire series. Organizing, researching, creating, and sharing this scholarly endeavor is a tremendous task. NSF support has been absolutely essential in moving the volume forward following its initial conception and design. Work on Cartography in the Nineteenth Century is now about two-thirds complete, and the entire volume is scheduled to be published by the end of 2027. Yet without NSF support, this volume—with all the new research it encapsulates and the new narratives it presents—would barely have gotten off the drafting table. NSF support has sustained the fundamental infrastructure of a long-term project, whose completion can now go forward with the assistance of other funders.
